data.title: Sports stars we lost in 2023 as Sports Personality of the Year pays tribute
meta_keywords: BBC Sports Personality of the Year
data.meta_description: 2023 saw us lose Sir Bobby Charlton, Terry Venables, Bill Kenwright, and many other much-loved sportspeople
data.text:
2023 saw us lose Sir Bobby Charlton, Terry Venables, Bill Kenwright, and many other much-loved sportspeople

Sports Personality of the Year 2023 will air this evening - Tuesday - on BBC One for what will be the 70th edition of the annual awards ceremony.

Hosts Gary Lineker, Alex Scott, Gabby Logan, and Clare Balding will take a look back at the highlights of 2023, including England's run up to the Women's World Cup final, Europe's win of the Ryder Cup, and a successful Rugby World Cup title defence for South Africa.

‌

Each year the event also pays tribute to sports stars we have lost this year.

READ MORE: 33 images from Bill Kenwright's memorial service as ex-Everton chairman remembered

READ MORE: BBC axing 10 channels as households urged to act now

‌

Liverpool Echo Icon

Sign up to FREE email alerts from ECHO Daily News

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you’ve consented to and improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and third parties based on our knowledge of you. More info

Football legend Sir Bobby Charlton died aged 86, on October 21. Charlton was a key member of England’s victorious 1966 World Cup team and also enjoyed great success at club level with United, who became the first English club to win the European Cup in 1968.

A statement on behalf of the Charlton family said: “It is with great sadness that we share the news that Sir Bobby passed peacefully in the early hours of Saturday morning. He was surrounded by his family.”

Charlton won 106 caps for England and scored 49 international goals - records for his country at the time.

‌

We also lost Terry Venables in 2023. The former England manager died aged 80 on November 26. Venables took the national team to the semi-final of Euro 96, as well as taking charge of Barcelona, Leeds and Tottenham during his managerial career.

Everton chairman Bill Kenwright died, age 78, on October 24. He had suffered with health issues for some time and recently had surgery to remove a cancerous tumour from his liver. A memorial service remembering the life of Bill Kenwright took place at Liverpool Cathedral on Monday afternoon.

A club statement released after the procedure said it had been successful, though complications had led to a period in intensive care. By October 12, the date of the update issued by Everton, he had left hospital and returned home for what was expected to be a long but complete recovery.

‌

Here is a list of sportspeople we tragically lost in 2023:

Jan 1 - Frank McGarvey 66 - former St Mirren, Celtic and scottish international - pancreatic cancer

January 5 - David Gold 86 - chairman of West Ham

Jan 8 - Ken Scotland 86 - Scottish rugby union player

Jan 8 - Ray Middleton 86 - British Olympic racewalker

Jan 9 - David Duckham 76 - English rugby union player

Jan 14 - John Wickham 73, british motor racing team owner

Jan 16 - John Bicourt 77, British Olympic middle-distance runner

Jan 19 - Peter Thomas 78, English-Irish footballer (Irish international)

Jan 19 - Anton Walkes 25, English footballer died in boat crash (Portsmouth, Atlanta United, Charlotte FB)

Jan 23 - Fred Lindop 84. British rugby league referee

Feb 6 - Peter Allen 76 - English footballer (Leyton Orient Milwall)

Feb 6 - Billy Thomson, 64, Scottish footballer (Partick Thistle, St Mirren, Dundee United, Clydebank, Motherwell, Rangers, Dundee, Scotland).

Feb 7 - Royden Wood, 92, English footballer (Leeds United).

Feb 12 - Tony Lee, 75, English footballer (Bradford City, Darlington).

Feb 16 - Kevin Bird, 70, English professional footballer (Mansfield Town, Huddersfield Town).

Feb 16 - Colin Dobson, 82, English professional footballer (Sheffield Wednesday, Huddersfield Town, Bristol Rovers).

Feb 23 - John Motson, 77, English football commentator (BBC Sport).[52]

Feb 27 - Sammy Winston, 44, English footballer (Leyton Orient).

March 1 – Allan McGraw, 83, Scottish football player (Morton, Hibernian) and manager.

March 13 - Alan Jones, 77, Welsh footballer (Swansea City, Hereford United, Southport).

March 14 - Chris Shevlane, 80, Scottish footballer (Hearts, Celtic, Hibernian, Morton).

March 16 - Don Megson, 86, English footballer (Sheffield Wednesday, Bristol Rovers) and manager (Bristol Rovers, Bournemouth).

March 21 - Willie Bell, 85, Scottish footballer (Leeds United, Scotland) and manager (Birmingham City).

April 1 - Ken Buchanan, 77, Scottish boxer, undisputed world lightweight champion

April 2 - Max Crabtree, 90, English professional wrestler and promoter (Joint Promotions)

April 4 - John Sainty, 76, English professional footballer (Reading, Bournemouth, Aldershot) and manager (Chester City).

April 8 - Kenneth McAlpine, 102, English racing driver.

April 13 - Willie Callaghan, 56, Scottish professional footballer.

April 16 - Eddie Colquhoun, 78, Scottish footballer (Scotland, Bury, West Bromwich Albion, Sheffield United).

May 8 - Neil Matthews, 66, English professional football player (Grimsby Town, Halifax Town, Stockpot County, Lincoln City) and coach.

May 11 - Andy Provan, 79, Scottish footballer (Barnsley, York City, Chester City, Wrexham, Southport, Torquay United).

May 13 - John Flood, 90, English professional footballer (Southampton, AFC Bournemouth).

May 22 - Hugh Strachan, 84, Scottish professional footballer (Motherwell, Greenock Morton, Kilmarnock, Partick Thistle).

June 3 - Josser Watling, 98, English professional footballer (Bristol Rovers).

June 6 - Mike McFarlane, 63, English sprinter, Olympic silver medallist (1988), heart attack

June 10 - Adrian Sprott, 61, Scottish footballer (Meadowbank Thistle, Hamilton Academical, Stenhousemuir).

June 13 - Paul Rendall, 69, English rugby union player (Wasps, national team).

June 15 - Gordon McQueen, 70, Scottish footballer (Leeds United, Manchester United, national team) and manager.

June 19 - Billy Bales, 94, English motorcycle speedway rider (Yarmouth Bloaters, Norwich Stars, Sheffield Tigers)

June 19 - Diane Rowe, 90, English table tennis player

June 26 - Craig Brown, 82, Scottish professional footballer and football manager.

June 30 - Robert Fernley, 70, British motorsport manager and entrepreneur

July 2 - Wayne Evans, 51, Welsh professional footballer (Walsall, Rochdale).

July 3 - Greig Oliver, 58, Scottish rugby union player

July 5 - Keith Ball, 82, English footballer (Walsall, Port Vale).

July 13 - Chris Garland, 74, English footballer (Bristol City, Chelsea, Leicester City).

July 14 - Tony Butler, 88, British sports broadcaster.

July 19 - Mike Hammond, 33, British ice hockey player (Nottingham Panthers), traffic collision

July 24 - Trevor Francis, 67, footballer, heart attack

August 1 - Tony Brien, 54, Irish footballer (Leicester City, Chesterfield, Rotherham United, West Bromwich Albion, Hull City).

August 9 - John Coddington, 85, English professional footballer (Huddersfield Town, Blackburn Rovers, Stockport County).

August 10 - Alec Jackson, 86, English footballer (West Bromwich Albion, Birmingham City, Walsall).

August 13 - Joe Caven, 86, Scottish footballer (Brighton & Hove Albion).

August 14 - Brian Snowdon, 88, English professional footballer (Blackpool, Portsmouth, Millwall, Crystal Palace).

August 16 - John Elsom, 84, English football chairman (Leicester City)

August 21 - Andy Rankin, 79, English professional footballer (Everton, Watford, Huddersfield Town).

August 22 - Bobby Noble, 77, English footballer (Manchester United).

September 2 - Mark Pearson, 83, English footballer (Manchester United, Sheffield Wednesday, Fulham, Halifax Town).

September 6 - Ian Hamilton, 55, English professional footballer (Cambridge United, Scunthorpe United, West Bromwich Albion, Sheffield United, Notts County, Lincoln City).

September 9 - John Harris, 84, English professional footballer (Wolverhampton Wanderers, Walsall).

September 16 - Colin Murphy, 79, English football player (Derby County, Lincoln City, Stockport County, Southend United) and manager (Notts County).

September 17 - Arthur Longbottom, 90, English footballer (Queens Park Rangers, Port Vale, Millwall, Oxford United, Colchester United).

September 17 - Ronnie McKinnon, 83, Scottish professional footballer (Rangers, Scotland).

September 21 - Robin Gladwin, 83, English footballer (Norwich City, Oxford United).

October 1 - Frank McDougall, 65, Scottish professional footballer (Clydebank, St Mirren, Aberdeen).

October 1 - John Waring, 81, English cricketer (Yorkshire, Warwickshire).

October 2 - Francis Lee, 79, English footballer (Manchester City, Bolton Wanderers, national team) and chairman, cancer.

October 2 - Gary Simpson, 64, English footballer (Chesterfield, Chester City).

October 4 - Tommy Hoyland, 91, English professional footballer (Sheffield United, Bradford City)

October 5 - Bill Munro, 89, Scottish football player (Barrow) and manager (Clydebank, Airdrieonians).

October 10 - Wilf Billington, 93, English footballer (Workington, Blackburn Rovers).

October 12 - Neil Le Bihan, 47, English footballer (Peterborough United).

October 13 - Hugh Russell, 63, boxer, Olympic bronze medallist

October 14 - Gwyn Richards, 71, Welsh cricketer

October 15 - Gerry Ryan, 68, Irish professional footballer (Republic of Ireland, Derby County, Brighton & Hove Albion).

October 16 - Gordon Low, 83, Scottish footballer (Huddersfield Town, Bristol City, Stockport County)

October 18 - Paul Reynolds, 50, English cricket umpire (Cricket Ireland)

October 20 - Gerry Cranham, 94, English sports photographer

October 21 - Sir Bobby Charlton CBE, 86, English footballer (Manchester United, national team) and manager (Preston North End), world champion (1966)

October 21 - Bill Gates, 79, English footballer (Middlesbrough).

October 23 - Desert Crown, 4, British racehorse, Epsom Derby winner (2022), euthanised

October 23 - Bill Kenwright, 78, English theater producer (Blood Brothers) and football administrator, chairman of Everton (since 2004), liver cancer

October 24 - Bob Pomphrey, 79, English cricketer (Hertfordshire)

October 26 – John Wilkie, 76, Scottish footballer (Halifax Town, Wigan Athletic)

October 28 - Domenico Genovese, 62, English professional football player (Peterborough United) and manager.

October 29 - Charlie Aitken, 81, Scottish footballer (Aston Villa)

October 31 - Ronnie Rees, 79, Welsh footballer

November 1 - Brian Hebditch, 75, British Olympic sports shooter (1976), traffic collision.

November 2 - John Havers, 92, English badminton player (national team)

November 6 - John Fahy, 80, Scottish footballer (Germiston Callies, Oxford United).

November 6 - Norman Munnoch, 94, Scottish rugby union player (Watsonian, Edinburgh District, national team)

November 7 - Stuart Jardine, 90, British Olympic sailor

November 8 - Dale Reid, 64, Scottish golfer

November 8 - Adrian Webster, 72, English football player (Seattle Sounders, Colchester United) and manager (Phoenix Inferno)

November 8 - Bob White, 87, English cricketer (Middlesex, Nottinghamshire).

November 9 - John Nuttall, 56, British long-distance runner who competed in track and cross country running.

November 13 - Gordon Wallace, 74, Scottish footballer (Raith Rovers, Dundee United, Berwick Rangers).

November 22 - Mike Bickle, 79, English footballer (Plymouth Argyle, Gillingham).[323] (death announced on this date)

November 24 - Henry Tilly, 91, English cricketer

November 25 - Terry Venables, 80, English football player (Chelsea, Tottenham Hotspur) and manager (national team)

November 28 - Rod Fletcher, 78, English footballer (Scunthorpe United, Lincoln City, Grimsby Town).[334] (death announced on this date)

November 28 - Cecil Sandford, 95, British motorcycle road racer, Grand Prix World Riders' Champion (1952, 1957).[336] (death announced on this date)

December 5 - Martin Patching, 65, English footballer (Wolverhampton Wanderers, Watford, Northampton Town).[350] (death announced on this date)

December 10 - Willie McCulloch, 75, Scottish football player (Alloa Athletic, Airdrieonians) and manager (Cowdenbeath).[353] (death announced on this date)
